What does it mean for lines or planes to be parallel? (The geometric definition)
Non-intersecting coplanar lines or non-intersecting planes.

• If two lines \(m\) and \(n\) are parallel we denote that \(m \parallel n\).
  • \(\parallel\) is read "parallel to".
yes
What are skew lines?
Lines that do not intersect and are not coplanar.
What are corresponding angles?
Given a transversal \(t\) that crosses coplanar lines \(m\) and \(n\). They are angles that lie on the same side of a transversal \(t\) and on the same side of lines \(m\) and \(n\).
Diagram
What is a transversal line?
A line that intersects two coplanar lines at two different points.

Diagram
  • Line \(t\) is a transversal line that intersects lines \(m\) and \(n\).
yes
What is the Corresponding Angles Axiom?
Two coplanar lines \(m\) and \(n\), cut by a transversal \(t\), are parallel if and only if each pair of corresponding angles is congruent.

Diagram
  • Here, two of the four pairs of corresponding angles are shown.
What is the Parallel-Transversal Theorem?

Given two lines \(m \parallel n\) cut by a transversal \(t\),

Then, \[\angle A_1 \cong \angle A_2 \cong \angle A_1' \cong \angle A_2'\] \[\angle B_1 \cong \angle B_2 \cong \angle B_1' \cong \angle B_2'\] And further any pair of \(\angle A\) and \(\angle B\) are supplementary.
yes
What is the Transversal-Parallel Theorem?

Given two lines \(m\) and \(n\) cut by a transversal \(t\) as in the picture below.

If any of the following statements are true
  1. \(\angle A_1\) or \(\angle A_2\) is congruent to either \(\angle A_1'\) or \(\angle A_2'\).
  2. \(\angle B_1\) or \(\angle B_2\) is congruent to either \(\angle B_1'\) or \(\angle B_2'\).
  3. \(\angle A_1\) or \(\angle A_2\) is supplementary to either \(\angle B_1'\) or \(\angle B_2'\).
  4. \(\angle B_1\) or \(\angle B_2\) is supplementary to either \(\angle A_1'\) or \(\angle A_2'\).
Then lines \(m\) and \(n\) are parallel.
• Note that this theorem relates angles in different intersections to allow us to conclude that the lines are parallel.
yes
What is the Parallel Axiom?
If given a line and a point not on the line, then there exists exactly one line through the point that is parallel to the given line.

• This is the most significant axiom in all of flat geometry. If this axiom is false, then it defines a different system of geometry.
  • If there are no parallel lines, that is a defining feature of what is called spherical geometry. Spherical geometry is very important to the study of navigation across the globe.
  • If there are infinite parallel lines, that is a defining feature of what is called hyperbolic geometry.
What is the Perpendicular Axiom?
If given a line and a point not on the line, then there exists exactly one line through the point that is perpendicular to the given line.
What is the process for finding the distance from a line, \(l\), to a point, \(P\), not on the line using coordinate geometry?

1. Find the equation for the line \(l\), in particular its slope.
  2. Use point-slope form to find the equation for the perpendicular line that runs through \(P\).
  3. Solve the system of equations to determine the point where the line \(l\) and the perpendicular line intersect.
  4. Find the distance between \(P\) and the intersection found in (3) and that is the total distance.

Diagram
  • Click the line or point to see the process.
What is an acute triangle?
A triangle with three acute angles.
yes
What is an obtuse triangle?
A triangle with one obtuse angle.
What is a right triangle?
A triangle with one right angle.
What is an equilateral triangle?
A triangle with three congruent sides.

• All equilateral triangles are equiangular.
  • Thus all equilateral triangles are regular.
What is an isosceles triangle?
A triangle with at least 2 congruent sides.
What is a scalene triangle?
A triangle with no congruent sides.
What is the Triangle Angle-Sum Theorem?
The sum of the measures of a triangle is \(180\) degrees.
What is an exterior angle of a triangle?
An angle like in the following diagram.
yes
What is Exterior Angle Theorem?

The measure of an exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the two remote interior angles.

That is the sum of the orange angles is equal to the blue angle in the following diagram
What are all the ways that triangle congruence be established?

1. Side-side-side Congruence. (SSS)
  2. Side-angle-side Congruence. (SAS)
  3. Angle-side-angle Congruence. (ASA)
  4. Angle-angle-side Congruence. (AAS)

Non-examples
  • Angle-angle-angle is insufficient to establish congruence.
  • Angle-side-side is also insufficient to establish congruence.
What is the Isosceles Triangle Theorem?
Two sides of a triangle are congruent if and only if the angles opposite those sides are congruent.
yes
What are the measure of angles in an equilateral triangle?
All angles are \(60\) degrees.
What is a perpendicular bisector of a line segment?
It is a segment, line, or plane that intersects a segment at a right angle and at its midpoint.
yes
What is the Perpendicular Bisector Theorem?
A point is on the perpendicular bisector of a segment if and only if it is equidistant from the endpoints of the segment.
Diagram
What are concurrent lines?
When three or more lines intersect at a common point.

• The point of intersection is called the point of concurrency.
Diagram
What is Circumcenter Theorem?
The perpendicular bisectors of the sides of a triangle intersect at a point that is equidistant from the vertices of the triangle.

• This point is called the circumcenter.
  • The circumcenter defines the center of the circle in which the the vertices of the triangle lie on it.
  • Since the radius of a circle is constant, the circumcenter must be equidistant from the vertices as required by the theorem.
Diagram
  • ProofDemonstration. Suppose we have a triangle \(ABC\). Then we draw the perpendicular bisector of both \(\overline{AB}\) and \(\overline{BC}\). The perpendiculars intersect (why?) and at a point we will call \(D\), by the perpendicular bisector theorem, \(AD = BD\) and \(BD = CD\). So \(AD = CD\) by the transitive property of equality and that means \(D\) is on the perpendicular bisector of \(\overline{AC}\) by the perpendicular bisector theorem. Q.E.D.
What is Angle Bisector Theorem?
A point is on the bisector of an angle if and only if the point is on the interior of an angle and equidistant from the sides of the angle.
Diagram
What is Incenter Theorem?
The angle bisectors of a triangle intersect at a point that is equidistant from the sides of the triangle.

• This point, \(C\), is called the incenter.
  • The incenter defines the center of the circle that touches all three sides of the triangle.
  • Since the radius of a cricle is constant, \(C\) must be equidistant from the sides as required by the theorem.
What is a median of a triangle?
A line segment from the vertex of the triangle to the midpoint of the opposite side.
Diagram
yes
What is Centroid Theorem?
The medians of a triangle intersect at a point that is two thirds of the distance from each vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side.

• The point is called the centroid.
  • The centroid is also called the center of gravity because it is the balance point of the triangle.
What is an altitude of a triangle?
It is the shortest line segment from a vertex of a triangle to the line containing the opposite side.
Diagram
yes
What is the Orthocenter Theorem?
The lines containing the altitudes of a triangle are concurrent.

• The point of concurrency is called the orthocenter.
  • If the triangle is acute, the orthocenter lies inside the triangle.
  • If the triangle is obtuse, the orthocenter lies outside the triangle.
  • If the triangle is right, the orthocenter will be one of the vertices of the right triangle.
What is the Angle-Side Relationships in Triangles Theorem?
Let \(a\) and \(b\) be sides of a triangle and \(\angle A\) and \(\angle B\) are their opposite angles.  \[a > b \iff m \angle A > m \angle B\]
What is a proof by contradiction?
A proof where we assume the negation of what we want to prove, and then show this leads to a logical impossibility.

• A proof by contradiction is also called an indirect proof.
  • A logical impossibility is called a contradiction or falsum.
  • A contradiction is denoted \(\bot\). This is the same notation as perpendicular. Though one will be used in the context of geometry and another in the context of logic.
  • A statement that is always true, a tautology, is denoted \(\top\).
  • \(\lnot \top \equiv \bot\) and \(\lnot \bot \equiv \top\).
What is the Triangle Inequality Theorem? (Geometry)
The sum of the lengths of any two sides of a triangle must be strictly greater than the length of the third side.

Example
  • The lengths \(4\) cm, \(3\) cm, and \(7\) cm can't be the side lengths of a triangle because \(4 + 3 \not> 7\).
What is Hinge Theorem?

Suppose that two sides of a triangle are congruent to sides of another triangle. Also suppose that \(\angle A\) and \(\angle B\) are the included angles of the triangles with opposite sides \(a\) and \(b\).
\[m \angle A > m \angle B \iff a > b\]
What is a diagonal of a polygon?
It is a line segment that connects any two nonconsecutive vertices of a polygon.
yes
What is the sum of interior angles of an \(n\)-gon?
\[(n-2) \cdot 180 \text{ degrees}\]
• This is called Polygon Interior Angles Sum Theorem.
What is the sum of exterior angles of a convex \(n\)-gon?
\[360 \text{ degrees}\]
• The sum of exterior angles does not depend on the number of sides of a polygon.
What are the four parallelogram tests?

If any of the following are true about a quadrilateral, then the quadrilateral is a parallelogram,
  1. Both pairs of opposite sides are congruent.
  2. Both pairs of opposite angles are congruent.
  3. The diagonals bisect each other.
  4. One pair of opposite sides are congruent and parallel.
What is the Rectangle Test Theorem?
A parallelogram is a rectangle if and only if the diagonals are congruent.
• This means we can test to see if a quadrilateral is a rectangle by testing if it is a parallelogram and also testing if its diagonals are congruent.
What is a rhombus?
A parallelogram where all four sides are congruent.
yes
What are the Rhombus Test Theorems?

1. A parallelogram is a rhombus if and only if its diagonals are perpendicular.
  2. A parallelogram is a rhombus if and only if each diagonal bisects its opposite angles.
What is the Rhombus Side Test?
If one pair of consecutive sides of a parallelogram are congruent, the parallelogram is a rhombus.
What is the Square Test? (Geometry)
If a polygon is both a rectangle and a rhombus, then it is a square.
What is a trapezoid?
A quadrilateral with exactly one pair parallel sides.

• The parallel sides are called bases.
  • The nonparallel sides are called legs.
  • Base angles are formed by the base and one of the legs.
  • A trapezoid with congruent legs is an isosceles trapezoid.
What are the Isosceles Trapezoid Theorems?

1. A trapezoid is isosceles if and only if both pairs of base angles are congruent.
  2. A trapezoid is isosceles if and only if its diagonals are congruent.
• In order to prove that a trapezoid is isoceles its only necessary to show one pair of base angles are congruent.
What is the midsegment of a trapezoid?
It is the segment that connects the midpoints of the legs of the trapezoid.
• Sometimes the midsegment is called the median, in our class we will not use this language.
What is the Trapezoid Midsegment Theorem?
The midsegment of a trapezoid is parallel to each base and its length is the average of the lengths of both bases.
What is a kite?
A quadrilateral with exactly two pairs of consecutive congruent sides.
• The opposite sides of a kite cannot be congruent or parallel.
What is the Kite Diagonal Theorem?
If a quadrilateral is a kite, then its diagonals are perpendicular.

• The diagonals being perpendicular is not sufficient to prove that a quadrilateral is a kite (a counterexample is a square or any rhombus).
  • Here is a sufficient statement: If the diagonals of a quadrilateral are perpendicular and the diagonals don't both bisect each other.
What are all the ways that triangle similarity be established?

1. Angle-Angle Similarity. (AA)
  2. Side-Side-Side Similarity. (SSS)
  3. Side-Angle-Side Similarity. (SAS)

• (1) is an axiom.
  • (2) and (3) are theorems.
What does the Similarity is an Equality Relation Theorem state?
Similarity is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.
What is Side-Splitter Theorem?
A line that intersects two sides of a triangle is parallel to the third side if and only if it divides the sides into segments of proportional lengths.
What is the midsegment of a triangle?
It is a segment with endpoints that are the midpoints of two sides of the triangle.
What is Triangle Midsegment Theorem?
A midsegment of a triangle is parallel to one side of the triangle and its length is half the length of that side.
What is an enlargement?
It is a dilation with a scale factor greater than one.
Diagram
What is a reduction? (Geometry)
It is a dilation with a scale factor between zero and one.
Diagram
What is a dilation? (Geometry)
A transformation that enlarges or reduces a figure proportionally.

• Dilations are performed with respect to a fixed point called the center of dilation.
  • Whether a dilation is an enlargement or a reduction depends on the value of its scale factor.
Diagram
What is a scale model?
A proportional drawing, sculpture, or 3D model of another location or object.
• The scale is the scale factor of dilation represented as a ratio.
What is the geometric mean of two positive numbers \(a\) and \(b\)?
\[\sqrt{ab}\]
What is the Right Triangle Altitude Theorem?
The altitude drawn from the hypoteneuse of a right triangle cuts the triangle into two similar triangles.
What is the Geometric Mean Theorem?
The altitude drawn from the hypotenuse separates the hypotenuse into two segments. The length of the altitude is the geometric mean between the length of these two segments.

Proof
  • Demonstration. In the preceeding diagram let the grey triangle be a right triangle and its altitude be the solid yellow line. Then by the Right Triangle Altitude Theorem the two triangles inside the large grey triangle are similar. And by matching up corresponding sides we have the following ratios, \[\frac{\color[RGB]{255,193,7}{\text{Altitude}}}{{\color[RGB]{216,27,96}\text{Dotted}}} = \frac{{\color[RGB]{30,136,229}\text{Dashed}}}{{\color[RGB]{255,193,7}\text{Altitude}}}\] Which implies that \[{\color[RGB]{255,193,7}\text{Altitude}}^2 = {\color[RGB]{216,27,96}\text{Dotted}} \cdot {\color[RGB]{30,136,229}\text{Dashed}}\] \[{\color[RGB]{255,193,7}\text{Altitude}} = \sqrt{{\color[RGB]{216,27,96}\text{Dotted}} \cdot {\color[RGB]{30,136,229}\text{Dashed}}}\] Q.E.D.
What is a Pythagorean triple?
A set of three positive integers that satisfies \(a^2 + b^2 = c^2\).

Examples
  • \(3\), \(4\), and \(5\) and its multiples are triples.
  • \(5\), \(12\), and \(13\) and its multiples are triples.
  • \(8\), \(15\), and \(17\) and its multiples are triples.
  • \(7\), \(24\), and \(25\) and its multiples are triples.
What are the Pythagorean Inequality Theorems?

If \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) are sides of a triangle with \(c\) being the longest side then, \[\begin{align}c^2 < a^2 + b^2 &\implies \text{The triangle is acute.} \\ c^2 > a^2 + b^2 &\implies \text{The triangle is obtuse.}\end{align}\]
What are the ratios of sides of a \(45-45-90\) triangle?
What are the ratios of sides of a \(30-60-90\) triangle?
What is an angle of elevation?
It is the angle from the horizon to the object being observed, where the observer is the angle vertex.
What is an angle of depression?
It is the angle formed between a horizontal line and an observer's line of sight to an object below the line.
What is a vector in two or three dimensions?
It is a directed line segment that has an initial point (start) and a terminal point (end).

Notation
  • Vectors are denoted \(\mathbf{v}\) or \(\vec{v}\).
  • \(|\mathbf{v}|\) denotes the magnitude of the vector and represents its length.
  • Vectors also have a direction.
What is the standard position of a vector?
It is a vector whose initial point is at the origin.
How do you add vectors in component form, \(\langle u_1, u_2 \rangle\) and \(\langle v_1, v_2 \rangle\)?
\[\langle u_1 + v_1, u_2 + v_2 \rangle\]
How do you multiply a vector, \(\langle v_1, v_2 \rangle\), by a scalar \(k\)?
\[\langle k v_1, k v_2 \rangle\]
What is a line of reflection?

It is a sort of flip transformation across the line where the line of reflection is the perpendicular bisector between each point not on the line and its reflected point.

A point on the line of reflection is the same as its reflected point.

• This necessarily means that a point and its reflected point are equidistant from the line of reflection.
Diagram
  • Here is a point reflected across the identity line, \(y = x\). Notice that the point and its reflection are always equidistant from the line of reflection.
How do we reflect a point, \((x,y)\), across the identity line, \(y=x\)?
\[(x,y) \mapsto (y,x)\]
What is a glide reflection?
It is the composition of a translation followed by a reflection in a line that is parallel with the translation vector.
What is a line of symmetry?
A line such that when a figure is reflected across it, the figure maps onto itself.
What is a figure with rotational symmetry?
A figure that can be mapped onto itself by a rotation between \(0\) degrees and \(360\) degrees about the center of the figure.
What is the order of (rotational) symmetry?
It is \(360\) degrees divided by the smallest angle of rotational symmetry.

• This smallest angle of rotational symmetry is called the magnitude of symmetry.
Examples
  • A square has order of symmetry \(4\) because \(\frac{360}{90} = 4\).
  • A regular hexagon has order of symmetry \(6\) because \(\frac{360}{60} = 6\).
What is planar symmetry?
It is a type of three dimensional symmetry where a figure can be mapped onto itself by reflection in a plane.
What is axial symmetry?
It is a type of three dimensional symmetry where a figure can be mapped onto itself by rotation strictly between \(0\) and \(360\) degrees around the axis line.
What is a chord of a circle?
A line segment with endpoints on the circle.
Diagram
What are concentric circles?
Coplanar circles that share a center.
What is a polygon inscribed in a circle?
A polygon whose vertices all lie on the circle.
What is a circle circumscribed about a polygon?
A circle that contains all the vertices of the polygon.
• Not all polygons can be circumscribed.
What is a minor arc as compared to a major arc of a circle?

The minor arc is the shortest path along a circle between two points on the circle.
The major arc is the longest path along a circle between two points on the circle.

The solid black line is the minor arc and the dashed black line is the major arc.
What is a semicircle?
An arc with endpoints that lie on a diameter of the circle.
What are congruent arcs?
Arcs in congruent circles that have the same measure.
What are adjacent arcs?
Arcs of the same circle that share exactly one point in common and otherwise do not overlap.
What is the length of an arc, \(s\), subtended by an angle of \(\theta\) degrees with a radius of \(r\)?
\[s = \frac{2 \pi}{360} \cdot \theta r\]
What is the Arc-Chord Theorem?
In two congruent circles, two minor arcs are congruent if and only if their corresponding chords are congruent.
What is the Chord-Center Theorem?
In two congruent circles, two chords are congruent if and only if they are equidistant from the center.
What is the area of a parallelogram? (the basic formula)
\[A = bh\] Where \(b\) is the base of the parallelogram and \(h\) is the height measured from that base.
What is the area of a triangle? (the basic formula)
\[A = \frac{1}{2}bh\] Where \(b\) is the base of the triangle and \(h\) is the height of the triangle measured from the base.
What is the area of a trapezoid? (the basic formula)
\[A = \left(\frac{b_1 + b_2}{2}\right)h\] Where \(b_1\) and \(b_2\) are the lengths of the bases and \(h\) is the height of the trapezoid measured from \(b_1\).
• If instead we have the length of the midsegment of the trapezoid, call it \(m\), then we have \[A = mh\] This is because \(m = \frac{b_1 + b_2}{2}\).
What is the area of a rhombus or kite? (the basic formula)
\[A = \frac{d_1 d_2}{2}\] Where \(d_1\) and \(d_2\) are the lengths of the diagonals.
What is the area of a circle?
\[A = \pi r^2\] Where \(r\) is the radius of the circle.
What is the area of the sector of a circle with an arc of \(x\) degrees?
\[A = \frac{x}{360} \pi r^2\] Where \(r\) is the radius of the circle.
What is an apothem?
It is the line segment that connects the center of a circle to the midpoint of a chord.
What is the area of a regular \(n\)-gon? (the apothem formula)
\[A = \frac{1}{2} aP\] Where \(a\) is the apothem and \(P\) is the perimeter of the polygon.
• \(P = ns\) where \(s\) is the length of a side.
What is an isometric view of a solid?
It is a perspective drawing from the corner of a solid.
What is a cross section of a solid?
It is the intersection of a solid with a plane.
What are lateral faces of a solid?
They are faces that are not bases. That is the faces that form the sides of a solid.
• Lateral faces intersect at lateral edges.
What is the altitude of a solid?
It is a perpendicular segment that joins the planes of the bases.
• The height is the length of the altitude.
What is the lateral area of a prism? (the basic formula)
\[L = Ph\] Where \(P\) is the perimeter of the base and \(h\) is the height of the prism.
What is the surface area of a prism? (the basic formula)
\[S = L + 2B = Ph + 2B\] Where \(L\) is the lateral area, \(B\) is the area of the base, \(P\) is the perimeter of the base, and \(h\) is the height of the prism.
What is the surface area of a cylinder?
\[S = L + 2B = 2 \pi r h + 2 \pi r^2\] Where \(L\) is the lateral area, \(B\) is the area of the base of the cylinder, \(r\) is the radius of the base, and \(h\) is the height of the cylinder.
What is the lateral area of a regular pyramid? (the basic formula)
\[L = \frac{1}{2} P l\] Where \(P\) is the perimeter of the base and \(l\) is the slant height of the pyramid.
What is the slant height of a pyramid?
It is the height of a lateral face.
What is the surface area of a regular pyramid? (the basic formula)
\[S = \frac{1}{2} P l + B\] Where \(P\) is the perimeter of the base, \(l\) is the slant height, and \(B\) is the area of the base.
What is the surface area of a cone?
\[S = L + B = \pi r l + \pi r^2\] Where \(L\) is the lateral area, \(B\) is the area of the base, \(r\) is the radius of the base, and \(l\) is the slant height.
What is the volume of a prism? (the basic formula)
\[V = Bh\] Where \(B\) is the base of the prism and \(h\) is the height of the prism.
What is the volume of a cylinder? (the basic formula)
\[V = Bh = \pi r^2 h\] Where \(B\) is the base of the cylinder, \(h\) is the height, and \(r\) is the radius of the base.
What is Cavalieri's Principle?
If two solids have the same height \(h\) and the same cross-sectional area at every level, then they have the same volume.

• Think of a stack of coins. Does the volume that the coins takes up changes as the coins are shifted around?
  • Cavalieri developed the ideas that began with Greek scientist Democritus (460-380 B.C.) and more considerably Archimedes (287-212 B.C.). These ideas were called the Method of Indivisibles and would eventually lead to the development of an important branch of calculus called integral calculus.
What is the volume of a pyramid? (the basic formula)
\[V = \frac{1}{3} Bh\] Where \(B\) is the area of the base of the pyramid and \(h\) is the height.
What is the volume of the cone? (the basic formula)
\[V = \frac{1}{3} Bh = \frac{1}{3} \pi r^2 h\] Where \(B\) is the area of the base of the cone, \(h\) is the is the height of the cone, and \(r\) is the radius of the base.
What is the surface area of a sphere? (the basic formula)
\[S = 4 \pi r^2\] Where \(r\) is the radius of the sphere.
What is a great circle of a sphere?
It is the intersection of a sphere with a plane that runs through the center of the sphere.
What is the volume of a sphere? (the basic formula)
\[V =  \frac{4}{3} \pi r^3\] Where \(r\) is the radius of the sphere.
What is spherical geometry?
Geometry done on the surface of a sphere. The lines of spherical geometry are great circles.
• In spherical geometry the sum of interior angles of a triangle are greater than \(180\) degrees.
If a shape is dilated by a scale factor of \(k\), how will its volume change?
Its volume will scale by a factor of \(k^3\).
What is a random variable?
It is a variable that can assume a set of values, each with fixed probabilities.
• Example: A coin can be represented by the random variable \(X\), where heads is given a value of \(1\) and tails is given a value of \(0\). So \(P(X=1) = 50\%\) and \(P(X=0) = 50\%\).
What is the Law of Large Numbers?
Given some probability experiment with finite mean, the difference between the average value of simulations and the expected value tends towards zero as the number of simulations becomes very large.
What is the definition of conditional probability of two events? (Algebraically)
\[P(A \mid B) = \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)}\] When \(P(A) \neq 0\).
What is the algebraic definition of events that are complements?
\[P(\lnot A) = 1 - P(A)\]

Notation
  • \(\lnot A\) is when the even \(A\) does not occur.
What is the negative exponent rule?
What is the difference of squares formula?
What are the forms of perfect square trinomials?
How do we define the \(n\)th root of a number \(a\) for a positive integer \(n\)?
\[\sqrt[n]{a} = b \iff b^n = a\] If \(n\) is even it must be that \(a \geq 0\) and \(b \geq 0\).
What is an equation?
It is a sentence that relates two expressions by an \(=\) symbol.
What is a constraint?
It is a condition that a solution must satisify.
What is an onto function?
A function where each element of the codomain has at least one element of the domain that maps to it.
What is a discrete relation?
A relation where elements of the domain are distinct and separate.
• Here is a graph of a discrete relation.
yes
What is a continuous relation?
A relation where the domain has an infinite number of connected points, such as in an interval or some region.
• Here is a graph of a continuous relation.
What is the independent variable of a relation?
The values that make up the domain.

• It is also called the input values.
  • Often it is the \(x\) variable.
  • Some other common input variables are \(t\) and \(\theta\).
What is the dependent variable of a relation?
The values that make up the range.

• It is also called the output values.
  • Often it is the \(y\) variable.
  • They are the values that depend on the input values.
What does \(f(x)\) mean?
The function \(f\) evaluated at \(x\).

• This is called function notation.
  • It does not mean \(f\) times \(x\) unless that is very clear from context.
  • Examples.
    • \(f(5)\) is \(f\) evaluated at \(5\).
    • \(f(x + 2)\) is \(f\) evaluated at \(x+2\).
What is the standard form of a line?
\[Ax + By = C\] Where \(A\), \(B\), and \(C\) are integers whose greatest common factor is \(1\) and \(A \geq 0\).

• Features of standard form.
    • \((0,\tfrac{C}{A})\) is the \(y\)-intercept.
    • \((\tfrac{C}{B},0)\) is the \(x\)-intercept.
    • \(-\tfrac{A}{B}\) is the slope.
  • Depending on how irrational numbers may be involved, it may not be possible to get a line into standard form. Take for instance a linear equation with a slope of \(\pi\).
  • Example.
    • \(3x + 5y = 12\) is in standard form and \(A = 3\), \(B=5\), and \(C = 12\).
  • Non-examples.
    • \(3x + 6y = 9\) is not in standard form because the GCF of the coefficients is not \(1\).
    • \(3x = -5y + 12\) is not in standard form because the \(y\) term is on the wrong side of the equation.
    • \(1.5x + 2y = 7\) is not in standard form because \(1.5\) is not an integer (we can fix this by multiplying by \(2\)).
What is a \(y\)-intercept?
Where a graph crosses the \(y\)-axis.

• Algebraically this will be when \(x=0\).
  • As a direct consequence of the vertical line test, a function can have at most one \(y\)-intercept.
What is a \(x\)-intercept?
Where a graph crosses the \(x\)-axis.

• Algebraically this will be when \(y=0\).
  • A function may cross the \(x\)-axis any number of times.
What is a piecewise-defined function?
A function that is defined in two or more pieces. Where each piece contains a different part of the domain.

Examples
  • The absolute value function is a special piecewise function, \[|x| = \begin{cases} -x, & x < 0 \\ \phantom{-}0, & x = 0 \\ \phantom{-}x, & x > 0 \end{cases}\]
  • The floor function is another with infinite pieces, \[\lfloor x \rfloor = \begin{cases} \hspace{0.85em}\vdots & \hspace{2.8em}\vdots \\ -1, & -1 \leq x < 0 \\ \phantom{-}0, & \phantom{-}0 \leq x < 1 \\ \phantom{-}1, & \phantom{-}1 \leq x < 2 \\ \phantom{-}2, & \phantom{-}2 \leq x < 3 \\ \hspace{0.85em}\vdots & \hspace{2.8em}\vdots \end{cases}\]
What is the floor function?
\(\lfloor x \rfloor\) is defined as the greatest integer less than or equal to \(x\). Which is to say, we strictly round down \(x\).

• Examples.
    • \(\lfloor 4.8 \rfloor = 4\).
    • \(\lfloor 8 \rfloor = 8\).
    • \(\lfloor -3.4 \rfloor = -4\).
  • This is also called a step function.
  • Similarly the ceiling function, \(\lceil x \rceil\) is defined as the least integer greater than or equal to \(x\). We instead strictly round up \(x\).
What is a family of functions?
A group of functions with some similar characteristics.
• The simplest function on which other functions in the family are based is called the parent function.
How do we solve a system of equations by graphing?
Graph all the equations simultaneously and the intersections are where solutions to the system of equations are.

Example
  • Graphing as a method can be particularly useful when the equations we have are non-linear and we don't know how to handle them algebraically.
What is linear programming?
It is the optimization of a linear utility function that is constrained in some finite region.

• By optimizing we mean to find a maximum or minimum.
  • The utility function can be outputing money or time or anything else we'd like to optimize.
  • The constrained region is called the feasible region.
  • When the feasible region is convex, the optimal point lies on the boundary of the region.
  • When the convex feasible region is a polygon, the optimal point is a vertex of the polygon.
How do we perform the following matrix multiplication? \[\begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} e & f \\ g & h \end{bmatrix}\]
\[\begin{bmatrix} ae + bd & af + bh \\ ce + dg & cf + dh\end{bmatrix}\]

Dot Product Definition
  • Let \(\mathbf{r}_m\) be a row vector from the first matrix and \(\mathbf{c}_n\) be a column vector from the second matrix. Then we define matrix multiplication of a \(2 \times 2\) matrix as the following matrix of dot products. \[\begin{bmatrix} \mathbf{r}_1 \boldsymbol{\cdot} \mathbf{c}_1 & \mathbf{r}_1 \boldsymbol{\cdot}  \mathbf{c}_2 \\ \mathbf{r}_2 \boldsymbol{\cdot} \mathbf{c}_1 & \mathbf{r}_2 \boldsymbol{\cdot} \mathbf{c}_2 \end{bmatrix}\]
How does matrix multiplication differ from real number multiplication?

• Matrix multiplication is not commutative.
  • Matrix multiplication is not always well defined.
• However it is still associative and there is a left and right distributive property of matrix multiplication (when multiplication is well defined).
Let \(A\) be a \(m \times n\) matrix and \(B\) be a \(p \times q\) matrix. When is \(AB\) well defined and what are its dimensions?
When \(n = p\) the multiplication is well defined and \(AB\) is an \(m \times q\) matrix.
What is a periodic function?
A function with repeating output at regular intervals.

• One complete pattern is called a cycle.
  • And the horizontal length of a cycle is called a period.
What does it mean for an equation to be an identity?
It is an equation that is true for every value of its variables.

• Examples.
    • \(2x = x + x\).
    • \(x^2 - y^2 = (x + y)(x+y)\).
    • \(x = x + 6 - 6\).
What is a relation?
It is a set of ordered pairs.

• The first values in the pairs are the inputs and they make up the domain.
  • The second values in the pairs are the outputs and they are part of the range.
Examples
  • Here is a simple finite relation.
    • \(\{(4,1),(2,3),(2,4)\}\).
  • A relation can also be infinite.
    • \(\{\ldots (-2,-2), (-1,-1), (0,0), (1,1), (2,2), \ldots\}\)
  • They also don't need to contain numbers.
    • \(\{(\text{Purple}, \text{Blue}), (\text{Basketball}, \text{Potato})\}\).
Where is a graph positive/negative?
When a graph is above/below the \(x\)-axis.

Diagram
  • The solid blue line is where the graph is positive.
  • The dotted orange line is where the graph is negative.
Where is a graph increasing/decreasing?
When a graph is sloping upwards/downwards.

• The solid blue line is where the graph is increasing.
  • The dotted orange line is where the graph is decreasing.
Where does a graph have local extrema?
When a graph has a point has a \(y\)-coordinate that is greater than all the surrounding nearby points or less than all the surrounding nearby points.

• Informally this is a peak or a valley.
    • A peak is called a relative maximum or a local maximum.
    • A valley is called a relative minimum or a local minimum.
Diagram
What is the end behavior of a graph?
The behavior of the graph as we move towards the extremes of the domain.
What is a rate?
It is a ratio of two measurements. Usually different units of measure.

• Examples.
    • Speed is a rate, \(\frac{\text{distance traveled}}{\text{time passed}}\).
    • Population growth is a rate, \(\frac{\text{population change}}{\text{time passed}}\).
    • Points per game is a rate, \(\frac{\text{points}}{\text{games}}\).
  • The word "per" almost always indicates a rate.
  • If the ratio compares something to one of something else, this is called a unit rate.
  • Unit Rate Examples.
    • Miles per hour.
    • Eggs per recipe.
    • Screen time per day.
What is a weighted average?
It is a type of mean where we multiply each data point by its weight and sum them. And then divide by the sum of the weights.

Example
  • Suppose we traveled at \(30\) miles per hour for \(2\) hours, \(40\) miles per hour for \(3\) hours, and \(15\) miles per hour for \(1\) hour. Then our average speed is, \[\frac{30(2) + 40(3) + 15(1)}{2 + 3 + 1}\]
How can we identify the graph of direct variation?
We may identify the graph because it is linear and it goes through the origin (the \(y\)-intercept is zero).
Graph
What is a constant function?
A function whose output is always the same value.

• The equation for a constant function is \(y = b\) where \(b\) is some constant number.
  • The graph of a constant function is a horizontal line.
Graph
What is the identity function equation?

• Whatever the input is, that is the output.
  • The identity function is linear, it has an \(x\)-intercept and \(y\)-intercept of \((0,0)\) so it is a direct variation equation as well.
What is extrapolation?
It is predicting values using the assumption that the pattern of the data continues beyond our range of observed data.

• Extrapolation can be useful, but in general it is not safe to extrapolate data.
  • If the data we have is linear and we continue the line, this is called linear extrapolation.
What is bivariate data?
Data with two variables.
What is a scatter plot?
A graph of ordered pairs on the coordinate plane.

• Positive, Negative, and No Correlation.
    • If the \(y\) values tend to increase as the \(x\) values increase, the data is said to be positively correlated.
    • If the \(y\) values tend to decrease as the \(x\) values increase, the data is said to be negatively correlated.
    • If there is no apparent trend in the \(y\) values as the \(x\) values increase, the data is said to be uncorrelated.
  • Example. Scatter plot comparing arm span to height in inches. This is data with a positive correlation.
What is interpolation?
It is predicting values inside our range of collected data.

• Interpolation in general is much more reliable than extrapolating.
  • If the data we have is linear and we find the line of best fit to predict data, this is called linear interpolation.
What is linear regression? (Informally)
It is an algorithm for finding the line of best fit.
• There are other lines of best fit, if we say "the" line of best fit, we are typically talking about the one generated by ordinary least squares regression.
What is a residual? (Statistics)
It is a difference between a predicted data point and actual data point.

• Residuals can be used to assess whether a prediction is good. A good prediction will have two primary characteristics to its plot.
    1. The residuals will have small absolute values.
    2. There will be no apparent pattern in the residual plot.
Diagram
  • You can see the residuals of this linear regression graphed on the \(x\)-axis.
  • The points on the graph can be manipulated by dragging them.
What is an order of magnitude?
It a number rounded to the nearest power of \(10\).

Examples
  • \(345 \rightarrow 10^2\).
  • \(92345 \rightarrow 10^5\).
  • \(0.004 \rightarrow 10^{-3}\).
  • \(4 \rightarrow 10^0\).
What is a rational equation?
A rational equation is an equation containing one more rational expressions.
What are some of the strategies for solving rational equations?

• For a rational equation of the form \(\frac{A}{B} = \frac{C}{D}\) we can cross-multiply to obtain the equation, \[AD = BC\] And then solve it as we would a polynomial equation.
  • For a rational equation of the form \(\frac{A}{B} + \frac{C}{D} = E\) we can combine the rational  expressionsions using common denominators to obtain the equation, \[\frac{AD + BC}{BD} = E\] And proceed from there.
What is a simple exponential equation?
An equation of the form \(a^p = a^q\) for \(a>0\).
• This is a good form of equation to recognize because it is equivalent to the simpler equation \(p = q\).
How would we solve an equation of the form \(a^p = a^q\) for \(a>0\)?
This is only true if \(p = q\), so we just need to solve that equation.
• This is because the exponential functions are one-to-one.
What is a radical equation?
An equation that involves a radical somewhere in the equation.
What is the power property of equality?
If \(a = b\) then \(a^n = b^n\).

• This is not always true in the other direction, when \(n\) is an even integer, it is not always true that \(a^n = b^n \implies a = b\). So we need to check for extraneous solutions when doing this.
  • However if \(n\) is not an even integer then \[a^n = b^n \implies a = b\]
What is a population? (Statistics)
It consists of all of the individuals or members of a group of interest.
yes
What is a sample? (Statistics)
It is a subset of the population that is selected to be representative of the whole population.
• Note the connection to the word sample space. In this case the sample space is the entire population.
yes
What is a simple random sample? (Statistics)
A sample in which each member of the population has an equal chance of being selected.
yes
What is a self-selected sample?
It is when members volunteer to be included in a sample.
yes
What is a convenience sample?
It is a sample where easily accessible and available members are the ones included in a sample.
yes
What is a stratified sample?
A sample in which members are divided into mutually exclusive groups that share similar characteristics.
yes
What is bias? (Statistics)
An error that results in a misrepresentation of a population.

• If a sample is sufficiently biased, it impossible to represent a population accurately.
  • Just because bias is an "error" does not mean that it is always avoidable. Often times we have to accept some amount of bias as inevitable, while limiting the bias that we can.
In statistics, {{c1::a survey}} is {{c2::response data that is collected from a sample regarding their characteristics, behaviors, or opinions}}.
What is an observational study?
Members of a sample are measured without being affected by the study.
yes
What is statistical inference?
When we use statistics of a sample to draw conclusions about the entire population.
yes
{{c1::A statistic}} is {{c2::a measure that describes a characteristic of a sample}}.

Examples
  • A sample mean is a statistic, it is denoted with a bar over a variable, \(\bar{x}\).
What is a parameter? (Statistics)
A measure that describes a characteristics of a population.
• Statistics are what we use to estimate parameters.
What is a negatively skewed distribution?
A distribution where the data below the mean is on average further from the mean.
Diagram
What is a positively skewed distribution?
A distribution where the data above the mean is on average further from the mean.
Diagram
What is a linear transformation? (Statistics)
Letting \(Y\) be our transformed data, \(X\) be our original data, we can write it as, \[Y = aX + b\]

• This means we transform the data in a linear way.
  • We can control the measures of central tendency; mean, median, and mode; with \(b\).
  • We can control the measures of spread, like the standard deviation, with \(a\).
    • Note that this will also change the measures of central tendency (unless they are zero).
What is a discrete random variable?
A random variable with a countable number of possibilities.
What are the probability axioms?

For a sample space \(\Omega\), event \(E\), and probability measure \(P\) that gives the probability of an event,
  1. \(P(E) \geq 0\).
  2. \(P(\Omega) = 1\).
  3. If \(E_1 \cap E_2 = \varnothing\), then \(P(E_1 \cup E_2) = P(E_1) + P(E_2)\).

• In words.
    1. The probability of any event is \(0\) or greater.
    2. The probability of anything happening is \(1\).
    3. If two events are mutually exclusive, then the probability of one event or the other happening is the sum of their probabilities.
What is the normal curve?
It is the graph of the normal distribution. Arguably the most important distribution in all of statistics and probability.

Normal Curve Equation
  • \(y = \frac{1}{\sigma\sqrt{2\pi}} \exp\left({-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{x - \mu}{\sigma}\right)^2}\right)\)
  • Where \(\exp\) is the natural exponential function, \(f(x) = e^x\).
What is a z-score?
It is the number of standard deviations a data point is from the mean. For a data point \(x\), with mean \(\mu\), and standard deviation \(\sigma\), we compute it as, \[z = \frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}\]
What is the problem of celestial motion?
This is a historical problem to discover why celestial bodies (planets, comets, etc.) move the way that they do.
yes
What is the extrema problem?
This was a historical problem to discover, for example, at what angle maximized the range of a cannon ball or what is the maximum and minimum distance of a planet from the sun.
What are the length and area problems?
This is a historical problem to find the length along a curve or the area under it.
• Euclidean geometry can approach the area under a curve by using the method of exhaustion. However this method is highly inefficient.
Who were the primary inventors of The Calculus?
Isaac Newton (1642-1727) and Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz (1646-1716).

• Early Developers of The Calculus
    • Pierre de Fermat (1601-1665).
    • Ren Descarte (1596-1650).
    • Balise Pascal (1623-1662).
    • Gillse Persone de Roberval (1602-1675).
    • Bonaventura Cavalieri (1598-1647).
    • Isaac Barrow (1630-1677).
    • James Gregory (1638-1675).
    • Christian Huygens (1629-1695).
    • John Wallis (1616-1703).
  • Important Later Contributors
    • James Bernoulli (1654-1705).
    • John Bernoulli (1667-1748).
    • Michel Rolle (1652-1719).
    • Brook Taylor (1685-1731).
    • Colin Maclaurin (1698-1746).
    • Leonhard Euler (1707-1783).
    • Jean Le Rond d'Alembert (1717-1783).
    • Joseph-Louis Lagrange (1736-1813).
  • Final Contributors
    • Bernhard Bolzano (1781-1848).
    • Augustin-Louis Cauchy (1789-1857).
    • Karl Weierstrass (1815-1897).
What is the root of the word calculus?
Pebble.
• This is becaus arithmetic used to be done with the aid of stones, as a sort of impromptu abacus for ancient greeks.
What is the power rule of differentiation?
\[\frac{d}{dx} x^n = n x^{n-1}\] For constant \(n\).
yes
What is the relationship between position, velocity, and acceleration? (Calculus)
Let \(s\) be position and \(t\) be time. \[\frac{ds}{dt} s = v\] \[\frac{ds}{dt} v = a\] Where \(v\) is velocity and \(a\) is acceleration.

• The first equation says "The rate of change of the position is velocity."
    • This is how we define what velocity is in the first place.
  • The second equation says "The rate of change of the velocity is acceleration."
    • This is how we define acceleration.
  • This means that \(\frac{d^2s}{dt^2} s = a\).
What is the antiderivative?
It is the inverse of the derivative operation.

• This is also called the integral.
  • Because \(\frac{d}{dx} C = 0\) when \(C\) is constant, we need to add an undefined constant \(C\) when we take the indefinite integral of a function.
What is the reflection property of a parabola?
Suppose the inside of a parabola is a reflexive surface. Light eminating from the focus of a parabola will be reflected perpendicular to the directrix.
What is the reflection property of an ellipse?
Suppose the inside of an ellipse is a reflexive surface. Light eminating from the focus of a ellipse will be reflected off the ellipse in such a way that it travels to the other focus..
What is the reflection property of a hyperbola?
Suppose that both sides of a hyperbola that are facing each other are a reflexive surface. Light pointed at one focus of a hyperbola will be reflected towards the other focus of the hyperbola.
What is the reverse power rule of integration?
\[\int x^n dx = \frac{x^{n+1}}{n+1} + C\]
• This rule does not work for \(n = 1\) as it would cause zero division.
What is the product rule of differentiation?
Let \(u\) and \(v\) be functions of \(x\), then \[\frac{d}{dx} (uv) = u'v+v'u\]
What is the quotient rule of differentiation?
Let \(u\) and \(v\) be functions of \(x\), then, \[\frac{d}{dx} \left(\frac{u}{v}\right) = \frac{u'v - v'u}{v^2}\]
What is the chain rule of differentiation?
Given functions \(f\) and \(g\) of \(x\), then \[\frac{d}{dx} f(g(x)) = f'(g(x))g'(x)\]
What is a straight angle?
An angle that measures 180 degrees.
• In particular this is the angle formed by two opposite rays. Since together two opposite rays form a line.
What is a vector space?
A field module.

Field Definition
  • A commutative ring whose nonzero elements form a group with respect to multiplication.
Module Definition
  • Consider a ring, \((R, *)\), with unity, \(\mathsf{1}\), and an abelian group, \((M,+)\). We define, \[R \times M \stackrel{\cdot}{\rightarrow} M\]
    1. \((\cdot)\) left and right distributes over \((+)\).
    2. The operations \((\cdot)\) and \((*)\) are associative with each other.
    3. \(\mathsf{1}\) is the identity for \((\cdot)\) as well as \((*)\).
yes
What is an endomorphism?
A homomorphism from an object to itself.
yes
What is a homomorphism?
A structure preserving mapping between two objects.
yes
What is a group?
An invertible monoid.
yes

{{c1::A monoid}} is a set along with a binary operation that is
  1. {{c2::Closed}}
  2. {{c3::Unital}}
  3. {{c4::Associative}}{{c5::ask-all}}
What is a ring? (Algebra)
An abelian group under addition that is also a monoid under multiplication that left and right distributes over the addition.
yes
What is an abelian group?
A commutative group.
yes
What is a field?
A ring where the nonzero ring elements form a group under multiplication.
yes
What is the geometric product of vectors \(\mathbf{u}\) and \(\mathbf{v}\) in \(\mathbb{G}^3\)?
\[\mathbf{uv} = \mathbf{u} \boldsymbol{\cdot} \mathbf{v} + \mathbf{u} \wedge\mathbf{v}\]
What is a category?

1. A class of objects.
  2. For each pair of objects, a hom-class, the class of morphisms between them.
  3. Morphisms compose.
  4. Every object paired with itself has an identity morphism.
Page 2
What is a class?
A collection of objects that does not contain a class.
yes
The category {{c1::\(\mathbf{Set}\)}} contains {{c2::all functions between sets}}.
The category {{c1::\(\mathbf{Mon}\)}} contains {{c2::all homomorphisms between monoids}}.
The category that contains homomorphisms between monoids.
The category {{c1::\(\mathbf{Grp}\)}} contains {{c2::all group homomorphisms between groups}}.
The category {{c1::\(\mathbf{AbGrp}\)}} contains {{c2::all group homomorphisms between Abelian groups}}.
The category {{c1::\(\mathbf{Mod}_R\)}} contains {{c2::all \(R\)-linear maps between \(R\)-modules}}.
The category {{c1::\(\mathbf{Vect}_F\)}} contains {{c2::all linear transformations between vector fields over \(F\)}}.
{{c1::\(\mathbf{Rng}\)}} is {{c2::the category that contains all rings and ring homomorphisms}}.
The category {{c1::\(\mathbf{CRng}\)}} contains {{c2::all ring homomorphisms between commutative rings}}.
The category {{c1::\(\mathbf{Field}\)}} contains {{c2::all ring embeddings between fields}}.
What is \(\mathbf{Poset}\)?
The category that contains monotone functions on partially ordered sets.
• Monotone functions are order preserving.
What is \(\mathbf{Rel}\)?
The category that contain subsets of cartesian products.
What is \(\mathbf{Top}\)?
The category that contains continuous functions on topological spaces.
What is \(\mathbf{SmoothMan}\)?
The category that contains smooth maps between manifolds.
What is a preordered category?
A category for which there is at most one morphism between every pair of objects.
• Sometimes called a thin category.
What is a product? (Category Theory)
Given objects \(X\), \(A\), and \(B\) along with their respective morphisms. The product is \(A \times B\) such that the diagram commutes.
What is a functor?
A morphism whose source and target are categories.
What is a covariant functor?
A functor that preserves arrow direction.
What is a contravariant functor?
A functor that reverses arrow directions.
What is a local arrow part of a functor?
The restriction of a functor to particular objects in the source category.

For example if the local arrow part of a functor, \(\mathcal{C} \xrightarrow{F} \mathcal{D}\), is one-to-one, that means for all objects \(A\) and \(B\) in \(\mathcal{C}\), \(\text{hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(A,B) \xrightarrow{F} \text{hom}_{\mathcal{D}}(F(A), F(B))\) is a one-to-one function.
What is a functor on \(\mathcal{C}\)?
A functor whose source and target are both \(\mathcal{C}\).
What is a set valued functor?
A functor whose target is \(\mathbf{Set}\).
What are parallel morphisms?
Morphisms with the same source and target.
What are antiparallel morphisms?
Morphisms with swapped sources and targets.
What is a full functor?
A functor whose local arrow parts are onto.
{{c1::A faithful functor}} is {{c2::a functor whose local arrow parts are one-to-one}}.
What is a fully faithful functor?
A functor whose local arrow parts are bijective.
What is an embedding of a category \(\mathcal{C}\) in \(\mathcal{D}\)?
A fully faithful functor \(\mathcal{C} \Rightarrow \mathcal{D}\) whose object part is one-to-one.
• This is a strong variation of the definition of an embedding. Sometimes called a full embedding.
What is a concrete category?
A category for which there exists a faithful set valued functor.
What is an abstract category?
A category for which there does not exist a faithful set valued functor.
• In particular it is a category that is not concrete.
What is a categorical sum?
Given objects \(Y\), \(A\), and \(B\) along with their respective morphisms. The categorical sum is \(A \amalg B\) such that the diagram commutes.
Prove that if \(\mathcal{C} \stackrel{F}{\Rightarrow} \mathcal{D}\) is one-to-one on objects, then \(F\mathcal{C}\) is a subcategory of \(\mathcal{D}\).

Demonstration. We need only show that there is closure of arrows in \(F\mathcal{C}\).

To check for closure, take arbitrary arrows, \(Ff\) and \(Fg\) in \(F\mathcal{C}\) as in this diagram.
Diagram
To show that \(F\mathcal{C}\) is closed we would need to show \(F(fg)\) is indeed the composition \((Ff)(Fg)\). So we need to show that \(fg\) is well-defined.

Since \(F\) is one-to-one on objects, \(FB\) can't have two different sources and we can draw the corresponding triangle with the confidence, see diagram. And this confirms that \(fg\) is possible since \(\mathcal{C}\) is a category.
Diagram

Thus we have closure in \(F\mathcal{C}\). And \(F\mathcal{C}\) is a category, and therefore a subcategory of \(\mathcal{D}\).

Q.E.D.
When is a morphism, \(A \stackrel{f}{\rightarrow} B\), pre-invertible?
When there exists a morphism \(f_p\) such that \[f_p f = 1_B\]
When is a morphism, \(A \stackrel{f}{\rightarrow} B\), post-invertible?
When there exists a morphism \(f_P\) such that \[ff_P = 1_A\]
What is an isomorphism? (Category Theory)
A morphism for which there is a two-sided inverse.
• If there is an isomorphism between \(A\) and \(B\) then we write \(A \approx B\) and say that \(A\) and \(B\) are isomorphic.
Prove that when a morphism is pre- and post-invertible, the inverses are equivalent.

Demonstration. Given an arrow in a category \(A \stackrel{f}{\rightarrow} B\). With pre-inverse \(f_p\) and post-inverse \(f_P\).
\[1_B f_P = f_p f f_P = f_p 1_A\] Q.E.D.
• Suppose \(f_p\) and \(f_P\) are distinct two-sided inverses. The above proof demonstrates this would be a contradiction.
Prove that the composition of two isomorphisms is an isomorphism.

Demonstration. Let \(f\) and \(g\) be isomorphisms. See that pre- and post-composition with \(g^{-1}f^{-1}\) result in identity morphisms. 
Q.E.D.
What is an epic morphism?
A morphism \(f\) that is pre-cancellable. That is for any parallel morphisms, \[fg = fh \implies g=h\]
• The common nomenclature is right-cancellable. But because we are doing composition from left to right, which is non-standard, we use a different terminology.
What is an monic morphism?
A morphism \(f\) that is post-cancellable. That is for any parallel morphisms \[gf = hf \implies g=h\]
• The common nomenclature is left-cancellable. But because we are doing composition from left to right, which is non-standard, we use a different terminology.
Prove that if \(f\) is a pre-invertible morphism then it is epic.
Demonstration. Start with parallel morphisms \(g\) and \(h\) such that \(fg = fh\). \[\begin{aligned} fg &= fh \\ f_p f g &= f_p f h \\ g &= h \end{aligned}\] Q.E.D.
• By duality a post-invertible morphism is necessarily monic.
Give an example of a category where a monic and epic morphism fails to be an isomorphism.
Consider the category with two objects and this arrow. The arrow is necessarily monic and epic, but is certainly not an isomorphism.
Prove that a pre-invertible morphism \(A \stackrel{f}{\rightarrowtail} B\) is necessarily an isomorphism.

Demonstration. Let \(f_p\) be the pre-inverse. \[ff_pf = f1_B = f = 1_A f\] Then since \(f\) is monic, \(ff_p = 1_A\). So \(f_p\) is also a post-inverse.

Therefore \(f\) is invertible with inverse \(f_p\). Q.E.D.
What is an initial object in a category?
There is one morphism from the initial object to every other.
What is a terminal object in a category?
There is one morphism from every object to the terminal object.
What is a zero object in a category?
An initial and terminal object.

• In other words, for every object \(A\) in the category there is exactly one morphism \(A \rightarrow 0\) and \(0 \rightarrow A\).
  • Morphisms that can be factored through the zero object are called zero morphisms.
Prove that there is exactly one zero morphism between any two objects, in a category with a zero object.

Proof of Lemma. Consider \(A \rightarrow 0\) and \(0 \rightarrow B\) for all objects \(A\) and \(B\). Since zero is both terminal and initial, the arrows are unique. Q.E.D.

Demonstration. Let \(X\) and \(Y\) be arbitrary objects in a category, maybe even the zero object. And consider an arbitrary composition that can be factored through zero. \[X \stackrel{f_1}{\longrightarrow} \cdots \stackrel{f_n}{\longrightarrow} 0 \stackrel{g_1}{\longrightarrow} \cdots \stackrel{g_m}{\longrightarrow} Y\] \[X \stackrel{f_1 \cdots f_n}{\longrightarrow} 0 \stackrel{g_1 \cdots g_m}{\longrightarrow} Y\] Apply the lemma twice and \((f_1 \cdots f_n g_1 \cdots g_m)\) must be the unique zero morphism from \(X\) to \(Y\). So any zero morphism in a composition will necessarily force the composition to be a zero morphism. Q.E.D.
What is an opposite category?
A category with the same objects and reversed arrows.
• This is also called the dual category.
What is a dual property? (Category Theory)
For category \(\mathcal{C}\) and property \(p\), the property holds in the dual of \(\mathcal{C}\). \[\mathcal{C} \text{ has } p^{\text{op}} \iff \mathcal{C}^{\text{op}} \text{ has } p\]
What is the principle of duality? (Category Theory)
For a set of properties \(\Pi\) and property \(p\). \[\Pi \Rightarrow p  \iff  \Pi^{\text{op}} \Rightarrow p^{\text{op}}\]

• If \(\Pi\) is self-dual. Then we get the simpler duality principle \[ \Pi \Rightarrow p \iff \Pi \Rightarrow p^{\text{op}}\]
  • If all categories contain a property, then all categories contain its dual property.
What is a slice category of \(\mathcal{C}\) under \(C\), \((C/\mathcal{C})\)?
A category with the following morphism such that the diagram commutes.
What is a slice category of \(\mathcal{C}\) over \(C\), \((\mathcal{C}/C)\)?
A category with the following morphism such that the diagram commutes.
What is a topological space \((X, \mathcal{T})\)?

\(\mathcal{T} \subseteq 2^X\) that satisfies the following.
  1. \(\varnothing \in \mathcal{T}\) and \(X \in \mathcal{T}\).
  2. \(\mathcal{T}\) is closed under arbitrary unions.
  3. \(\mathcal{T}\) is closed under finite intersections.

• \(\mathcal{T}\) is called a topology on \(X\).
  • \(X\) is a space.
What is an open set of a topology \((X, \mathcal{T})\)?
An element of \(\mathcal{T}\).
What is a closed set of a topology \((X, \mathcal{T})\)?
A set, \(A\), such that \(X \setminus A \in \mathcal{T}\).
What is the discrete topology on \(X\)?
The topology that is the power set of \(X\).

Notation
  • The power set may be denoted \(\mathcal{P}(X)\).
  • It may also be denoted \(2^X\). A reference to the cardinality of the power set.
What is the indiscrete topology on \(X\)?
The topology that is \(\{\varnothing, X\}\).
• Also called the trivial topology.
What does it mean for topology \(\mathcal{T}\) to be coarser than \(\mathcal{T}'\)?
\[\mathcal{T} \subseteq \mathcal{T}'\]
• We also say \(\mathcal{T}'\) is finer than \(\mathcal{T}\).
What is a basis \(\mathcal{B}\) for a topology on \(X\)?

A collection of subsets of \(X\). Let \(B_i \in \mathcal{B}\) then the following define a basis.
  1. \(\mathcal{B}\) covers \(X\).
  2. For \(x\) in \(B_1 \cap B_2\) there is at least one \(B_3 \in \mathcal{B}\) such that \(x \in B_3 \subseteq B_1 \cap B_2\).
• The topology \(\mathcal{T}\) generated by the basis \(\mathcal{B}\) is defined to be the coarsest topology containing \(\mathcal{B}\).
What is a basic open neighborhood of \(x\)? (Topology)
Given a topological basis \(\mathcal{B}\), it is any \(B \in \mathcal{B}\) such that \(x \in B\).
How can we determine if a set is open with respect to a basis? (Topology)
Then a set \(U\) is open in the topology generated by a basis if and only if for all \(x \in U\), \(x\) is in a basic open neighborhood contained by \(U\).
What is the definition of a metric space? Specifically, define a metric.

A function \(X \times X \stackrel{d}{\rightarrow} \mathbb{R}^{+}_*\) that satisfies the following,
  1. \(d\) is symmetric.
  2. \(d\) satsifies the triangle inequality.
  3. \(d\) is only zero in the case \(d(x,x)\).
• \(d\) is called a metric or a distance function.
What is a ball centered at \(x\) of radius \(r\) in a metric space \((X,d)\)?
Every point within an \(r\) distance of \(x\). \[B(x,r) = \{y \in X \mid d(x,y) < r\}\]
What is a metric topology?
A topology whose basis is the set of all balls in space.
What is a metrizable space? (Topology)
A space that admits a metric topology.
• Note there are no restrictions on what the metric needs to be. As long as there is a metric such that this is true.
What is a continuous function between two topological spaces, \(X \stackrel{f}{\rightarrow} Y\)?

If \(f\) maps to an open set, then the input was open in \(X\).

That is to say, when \(U\) is open in \(Y\), the preimage of \(U\) under \(f\), \(\{x \in X \mid f(x) \in U\}\), is open in \(X\).

• We can define continuity at a point, \(x\). Let \(U\) be a neighborhood of \(x\) and \(V\) be a neighborhood of \(f(x)\).
    • \(f\) is continuous at \(x\) if for all \(V\) there exists a \(U\) such that \(f(U) \subseteq V\).
What is a complete metric space?
A metric space where every Cauchy sequence converges to a point in the space.
• Intuitively, we may think of this as a metric space that does not have missing points.
What is the probability distribution of the Poisson distribution?
\[p(k; \lambda) = \frac{\lambda^k e^{-k}}{k!}\] For \(k \in \mathbb{N}\).

Derive the moment-generating function of the Poisson distribution from its probability density function.

Demonstration.
\[\begin{aligned} M_X(t) &= {{c1::\sum\limits_{k \in \mathbb{N} } e^{kt} \frac{\lambda^k e^{-\lambda} }{k!} }}\\ &= {{c2::e^{-\lambda} \sum\limits_{k \in \mathbb{N} } \frac{(\lambda e^t)^k}{k!} }}\\ &= {{c3::e^{-\lambda} \cdot e^{\lambda e^t} }} \\ &= {{c3::e^{\lambda(e^t-1)} }} \end{aligned}\] Q.E.D.{{c4::ask-all}}
What is the moment generating function of a random variable \(X\)?
\[M_X(t) = \int\limits_{\Omega} e^{tx} \mathrm{d}\mathbb{P}\]
• This is the Lebesgue-Stieltjes integral.
What is a \(\sigma\)-algebra?

Let \(\mathcal{S}\) be a nonempty collection of subsets of \(\Omega\).
  1. \(\Omega \in \mathcal{S}\).
  2. \(\mathcal{S}\) is closed under complement.
  3. \(\mathcal{S}\) is closed under countable union.
  4. \(\mathcal{S}\) is closed under countable intersection.

{{c1::A measure over a \(\sigma\)-algebra}} is
\(\Omega \stackrel{\mu}{\rightarrow}\) {{c2::\(\mathbb{R}^+_*\)}} such that
  1. {{c3::\(\mu(\varnothing) = 0\)}}
  2. {{c4::\(\mu\) is countably additive}}{{c5::ask-all}}
What does it mean for a set function \(f\) on an algebra of sets to be countably additive?
For any countable number of disjoint sets \(A_i\), \[f\left(\bigcup A_i \right) = \sum f(A_i)\]
What is an algebra of sets?

Let \(\mathcal{A} \subseteq 2^{\Omega}\).
  1. \(\mathcal{A} \in \Omega\).
  2. \(\mathcal{A}\) is closed under complement.
  3. \(\mathcal{A}\) is closed under finite union (or equivalently finite intersection).
What is a hom-functor?

Given a locally small category \(\mathcal{C}\). For fixed \(X\) in \(\mathcal{C}\), define it as \(\mathcal{C} \stackrel{\mathcal{C}(X,-)}{\longrightarrow} \mathbf{Set}\) for every morphism \(Y \stackrel{f}{\rightarrow} Z\) in \(\mathcal{C}\) as in the following diagram, where \(f_*\) is pre-composition by \(f\).
• Or contravariantly, define \(\mathcal{C} \stackrel{\mathcal{C}(-,X)}{\longrightarrow} \mathbf{Set}\), where \(f^*\) is post-composition by \(f\).
What is the adjugate of a square matrix?
It is the transpose of the cofactor matrix.

Notation
  • We denote the adjugate of \(\mathbf{A}\) as \(\text{adj}(\mathbf{A})\).
  • Importantly, when \(A\) is invertible, it satisfies the equation, \[\text{adj}(\mathbf{A})\mathbf{A}=\mathbf{A} \,\text{adj}(\mathbf{A}) = \det(\mathbf{A})\mathbf{I}\]
What is the characteristic polynomial of a square matrix?
\[\det(A-t I_n)\]

Notation
  • We may write \(p_A(t)\) to represent the characterstic polynomial.
What is the Cayley-Hamiltom theorem?
Every square matrix over a commutative ring satisfies its own characteristic polynomial. That is, \[p_{\mathbf{A}}(\mathbf{A}) = \mathbf{0}\]
• Where \(p_{\mathbf{A}}(\lambda) = \det(\mathbf{A}-\lambda \mathbf{I}_n)\), the characteristic equation.
Prove that the eigenvalues of a matrix are the zeros of its characteristic polynomial.

Demonstration. For an \(n \times n\) matrix \(\mathbf{A}\), an eigenvalue is a solution to the following equation, for nonzero \(n\)-column vector \(\mathbf{v}\),\[\begin{aligned}\mathbf{A} \mathbf{v} &= \lambda \mathbf{v} \\ \mathbf{A} \mathbf{v} - \lambda \mathbf{v} &= \mathbf{0} \\ (\mathbf{A} - \lambda \mathbf{I})\mathbf{v} &= \mathbf{0}\end{aligned}\] Since \(\mathbf{v}\) is nonzero, \(\mathbf{A} - \lambda \mathbf{I}\) is not invertible. Therefore \(\det(\mathbf{A}- \lambda \mathbf{I}) = 0\).

Q.E.D.
Prove that if two matrices \(AB = \mathbf{0}\) where \(B \neq \mathbf{0}\), then \(A\) is not invertible.

Demonstration. Suppose that \(AB = \mathbf{0}\) and further \(B \neq \mathbf{0}\). By way of contradiction, suppose that \(A\) is invertible. Then we have the following, \[\begin{aligned} B &= (A^{-1}A)B \\ &= A^{-1}(AB) \\ &= A^{-1} \mathbf{0} \\ &= \mathbf{0} \end{aligned}\]But \(B \neq \mathbf{0}\), this is the contradiction we sought. Q.E.D.
Prove that the characteristic polynomial of a diagonalizable linear operator on a field, \(\mathsf{T}\), splits over the field.

Demonstration. Let \([\mathsf{T}]_{\beta} = \mathbf{D}\) be a diagonal representation of \(\mathsf{T}\). Then the characteristic polynomial is,\[\det(\mathbf{D}-t\mathbf{I}) =\prod (\lambda_i - t)\]Which is exactly what it means for a polynomial to split. Q.E.D.
What does it mean for two matrices to be similar?
Matrices \(A\) and \(B\) are similar if there exists a square invertible matrix \(P\) such that, \[A = P^{-1}BP\]

• Similarity is an equality relation on matrices.
  • Some properties preserved by similarity.
    • Rank.
    • Characteristic polynomial.
      • Determinant.
      • Trace.
      • Eigenvalues.
    • Rank of eigenspaces.
    • Nilpotency.
  • Some properties not preserved by similarity.
    • Symmetry and skew-symmetry.
    • Orthogonality.
    • Frobenius Norm.
What does it mean for a matrix, \(A\), to be diagonalizable? (The basic definition)
\(A\) is similar to a diagonal matrix.
How can we determine if a matrix is diagonalizable using eigenvectors?
A matrix is diagonalizable if and only if it has an eigenbasis.

• A matrix has an eigenbasis if two conditions are satisfied.
    1. The characteristic polynomial of the matrix splits.
    2. For each eigenvalue, the multiplicity of the eigenvalue is equal to the dimension of its corresponding eigenspace.
How can we determine if \(\lim\limits_{n \rightarrow \infty} A^n\) exists for a square matrix \(A\) with complex entries?

The limit exists if and only if,
  1. All eigenvalues of \(A\) are either \(1\) or inside the open complex unit disc.
  2. \(\dim(E_1(A)) = \text{multiplicity of } 1\).

• Here is a only slightly stronger, but simpler statement for convergence.
    1. All eigenvalues of \(A\) are either \(1\) or inside the open complex unit disc.
    2. \(A\) is diagonalizable. Which implies condition (2) above.
What is a left stochastic matrix?
A matrix of probability column vectors.

• Similarly a right stochastic matrix is a matrix of probability row vectors.
  • A doubly stochastic matrix has rows and columns that are probability vectors.
What is a probability vector?
A nonegative real vector whose entries sum to \(1\).
What is a regular stochastic matrix?
A stochastic matrix where there exists some power of the matrix that contains only positive entries.
What does it mean for \(\mu\) and \(\nu\) to be mutually singular measures of \(X\)?
The supports of \(\mu\) and \(\nu\) partition \(X\).

Notation
  • We write \(\mu \perp \nu\), as their support is orthogonal.
Examples
  • The Lebesgue measure, \(\lambda\), and the Dirac delta distribution, \(\delta_0\), are mutually singular measures on \(\mathbb{R}\).
    • \(\lambda({0})=0\) and \(\delta_0({0}) = 1\).
    • Let \(U\) be an open set in \(\mathbb{R}\) that does not include \(0\). \(\lambda(U)>0\) and \(\delta_0(U)=0\).
What does it mean for measure \(\mu\) to be absolutely continuous with respect to measure \(\nu\)?
For all measurable sets \(A\), \(\nu(A) = 0\) implies that \(\mu(A) = 0\).

Notation
  • We write \(\mu \ll \nu\).
  • We may also say that \(\nu\) dominates \(\mu\).
  • The support of \(\mu\) is a subset of the support of \(\nu\).
What is the Cantor ternary set?

It is the following limit of this sequence of intervals: Start with the interval \([0,1]\), then at each step delete the middle thirds of all intervals. This leaves the upper and lower third of each interval.

This set is precisely the following set of ternary fractions,
\[\left\{\sum\limits_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{a_k}{3^k} \;\Big\vert\; a_k = 0 \text{ or } a_k= 2 \right\}\]

Diagram
  • This is a visualization of the first 5 deletions.
  • At each step there are \(2^n\) intervals.
What is the uinversal trigonometric substitution?

Let \(f\) be a rational function. Then to solve \(\int f(\cos \theta, \sin \theta) d\theta\), then we let \(t = \tan \tfrac{\theta}{2}\) to make the following substitution,\[\int f\left(\frac{1-t^2}{1+t^2}, \frac{2t}{1+t^2}\right)\frac{2dt}{1+t^2}\]

• For \(t \in \mathbb{R}\), \(\left(\tfrac{1-t^2}{1+t^2}, \tfrac{2t}{1+t^2}\right)\), is every point in the unit circle except \((-1,0)\). But this point is approached in the limit as \(t\) goes to \(\pm \infty\).
Prove that \(\sin \theta = \tfrac{2t}{1+t^2}\) where \(t = \tan \tfrac{\theta}{2}\).

Demonstration.

Let \(s = \sin \tfrac{\theta}{2}\) and \(c = \cos \tfrac{\theta}{2}\). And note that \(1 = c^2 + s^2\) by the Pythagorean Theorem. And use the sine addition formula to get, \[\sin \theta = 2cs
= \frac{2cs}{c^2 + s^2}\] Then divide the numerator and denominator by \(c^2\) and simplify to obtain, \[\sin \theta = \frac{2t}{1+t^2}\] Q.E.D.
Prove that \(\cos \theta = \tfrac{1 - t^2}{1+t^2}\) where \(t = \tan \tfrac{\theta}{2}\).

Demonstration.

Let \(c = \cos \tfrac{\theta}{2}\) and \(s = \sin \tfrac{\theta}{2}\). And note that \(1 = c^2 + s^2\) by the Pythagorean Theorem. \[\cos \theta = c^2 - s^2 = \frac{c^2 - s^2}{c^2 + s^2}\] Then divide the numerator and denominator by \(c^2\) and simplify to obtain, \[\cos \theta = \frac{1 - t^2}{1+t^2}\] Q.E.D.
For \(t = \tan \tfrac{\theta}{2}\), derive \(d\theta\) in terms of \(t\) and \(dt\).

Demonstration. 

By the derivative of tangent, chain rule, and Pythagorean Identity; we have,
\[dt = \tfrac{1}{2}\left(\sec^2 \tfrac{\theta}{2}\right) d\theta = \tfrac{1}{2}\left(1 + t^2\right)d\theta\] Therefore we may conclude, \[d\theta = \frac{2 dt}{1 + t^2}\] Q.E.D.
What is a proper rational function?
A rational function, \(\tfrac{P(x)}{Q(x)}\), where \(P(x)\) is less than degree of \(Q(x)\) and both are real polynomials.
How do we perform Lagrange Interpolation for a set of data \((x_i, y_i)\)?
\[P(x) = \sum\limits_i \left(y_i \prod_{j\neq i}\left(\frac{x-x_j}{x_i-x_j}\right)\right)\]
What is the optimal way to prevent Runge phenomenon while interpolating polynomials?
By selecting Chebyshev points. For \(n\) data points on the interval \([-1,1]\), the points are, \[\mathop{\LARGE{\mathsf{\Psi} } }\limits_{k=1}^n \cos\left(\frac{2k-1}{2n} \pi\right)\]
• We can select Chebyshev points on any interval \([a,b]\) by centering the points at the midpoint of \([a,b]\) and then scaling cosine by half the length of the interval.
What is a Vandermonde matrix?

It is a matrix whose rows are polynomials in \(x_i\), columns are coefficients of a polynomial we wish to interpolate, such that, \[\mathbf{y} = \mathbf{V}\mathbf{a}\] Where the data points are \((x_i,y_i)\) and the column of coefficients is \(\mathbf{a}\).
What is a preorder or quasiorder?
A reflexive and transitive relation.

• A skeletal (antisymmetric) preorder is a partial order.
  • A symmetric preorder is an equivalence relation.
What is an equivalence class?
It is a subset \(X\) where \(X\) has an equivalence relation \(\sim\), defined in the following way, \[[a] = \{x \in X \mid a \sim x\}\]
{{c1::A quotient set}} is {{c2::the partition of a set into its equivalence classes defined for some equivalence relation.}}
What is a quotient algebra?
It is the partitioning of an algebraic structure using a congruence relation.
What is a congruence relation? (Algebra)
It is an equivalence relation that is compatible with some algebraic structure.
What is the derivitative of an invertible function in terms of its inverse?

Let function \(f\) have inverse function \(g\). Then we have,
\[f'(x) = \frac{1}{g'(f(x))}\] For \(g'(f(x)) \neq 0\).

• The derivitave of logarithms can easily be found using this theorem, \[\frac{d}{dx} \ln x = \frac{1}{e^{\ln x}} = \frac{1}{x}\]
Proof
  • Demonstration. By the inverse function property \(g(f(x)) = x\). So the derivative of this composition must be \(1\). By the chain rule we have \(g'(f(x))f'(x) = 1\). Rearranging, we have, \[f'(x) = \tfrac{1}{g'(f(x))}\] Q.E.D.
What is the total derivative?

A generalization of the derivative for a vector valued function, \(\mathbf{f}\).

A function \(\mathbf{f}\) is totally differentiable if and only if each of its components\(f_i\) are differentiable.

And when it exists it is the Jacobian matrix of \(\mathbf{f}\).
What is the chain rule for total derivatives?

Let \(\mathbf{f}\) and \(\mathbf{g}\) be totally differentiable functions, then, \[\mathbf{J}_{\mathbf{fg}} = \mathbf{J}_{\mathbf{f}} \mathbf{J}_{\mathbf{g}}\] Where \(\mathbf{J}\) is the Jacobian matrix.
What are the three characteristics that define the information provided by an event?

Let \(\text{I}\) be the information provided by a probability.
  1. \(\text{I}\) is strictly decreasing in \(p\).
  2. \(\text{I}(1) = 0\).
  3. \(\text{I}(p_1 \cdot p_2) = \text{I}(p_1) + \text{I}(p_2)\) for when \(p_1\) and \(p_2\) are probabilities of independent events.

• Notice that (1) guarantees that \(\text{I}\) is invertible and (2) and (3) are the inverse of the statements that define the exponential function.
  • So up to scaling this uniquely determines the information provided by an event as \(\text{I}(p) = - \log(p)\).
What is the entropy of a random variable?
For a random variable \(X\), we define the entropy in bits, \[\text{H}(X) = \mathbb{E}[\text{I}(X)] = \mathbb{E}[-\log_2(X)]\]

• \(\text{H}\) is the capital Greek letter Eta, representing the entropy function.
  • \(\text{I}\) is the information content.
  • \(\mathbb{E}\) is the expectation.
Alternative Characterization
  1. \(\text{H}\) is continuous.
  2. \(\text{H}\) is symmetric.
  3. \(\text{H}\) is maximized over uniform events.
  4. For equiprobable outcomes, the entropy increases as we increase the number of outcomes.
  5. \(\text{H}\) is sigma-additive.
What is the null space of a matrix?
Given a matrix \(\mathbf{A}\), \[\{\mathbf{x} \mid \mathbf{Ax} = \mathbf{0}\}\]

Notation
  • \(\text{Null}(\mathbf{A})\).
  • \(\text{ker}(\mathbf{A})\).
  • The null space may also be called the kernel.
How can we directly compute the null space of a matrix \(\mathbf{A}\)?

\[\left[\mathbf{A}^t \mid \mathbf{I}\right] \xrightarrow{\text{rref}} \left[\mathbf{B} \mid \mathbf{C}\right]\] The span of the row vectors in \(\mathbf{C}\) corresponding to the zero rows of \(\mathbf{B}\), is the null space. And transpose the rows if column vectors are desired.
{{c1::An eigenspace of a matrix \(\mathbf{A}\)}} is {{c2::\(\ker(\mathbf{A} - \lambda \mathbf{I})\)}}.
Note that this particular eigenspace is associated with \(\lambda\).
Suppose that \(c\) is a real zero of a polynomial \(P\) with odd multiplicity, what is the shape of the graph near the \(c\)?
The graph will pass through the \(x\)-axis.
What is the domain of \(\sec\)?
All real numbers other than \(\frac{\pi}{2} + n \pi\) for \(n \in \mathbb{Z}\).
What is the period of \(\sin (kx)\)? (\(k>0\))
What is the period of \(\cos (kx)\)? (\(k>0\))
What is the \(\cos\) addition formula?
\[\cos(\alpha + \beta) = \cos \alpha \cos \beta - \sin \alpha \sin \beta\]
What is the formula for lowering the power of \(\sin\)?
\[2\sin^2 \theta = 1 - \cos 2 \theta\]
What is the parametric equation for the \(y\)-value of a cycloid starting at the origin and rolling on the circumference of a circle of radius \(r\)?
\[y = r - r \cos \theta\]
A function \(f\) is {{c1::logarithmically functional}} iff \[{{c2::f(xy) = f(x) + f(y)}}\]
This is one of the four Cauchy Functional Equations.
A function \(f\) is said to be {{c1::exponentially functional}} iff \[{{c2::f(x+y) = f(x) f(y)}}\]
This is one of the four Cauchy Functional Equations.
A function \(f\) is {{c1::multiplicative}} iff \[{{c2::f(xy) = f(x) f(y)}}\]

• This is one of the four Cauchy Functional Equations.
  • And in certain contexts \(x\) and \(y\) must satisfy certain conditions, such as in Number Theory.
A function \(f\) is {{c1::additive}} iff \[{{c2::f(x+y) = f(x) + f(y)}}\]
This is one of the four Cauchy Functional Equations.
{{c1::A convex combination}} is {{c2::a linear combination}} where all {{c2::coefficients}} are {{c3::positive}} and {{c4::sum to 1}}.{{c5::ask-all}}
In statistics, {{c1::the midhinge}} is {{c2::the mean of \(Q_1\) and \(Q_3\)}}.
This is equivalent to the median in a symmetric distribution. And its difference from the median is used as a robust metric of skewness of sample data.
quartile
In statistics, MH stands for {{c1::midhinge}}.
In statistics, MAD stands for {{c1::median absolute deviation}}.
In statistics, \[\operatorname{MAD}(\mathbf{x}) = {{c1::\operatorname{median}\left(\left| x_i - Q_2 \right|\right)}}\]
Where \(\mathbf{x}\) is the data, \(x_i\) are the data points, and \(Q_2\) is the median of the original data.
median absolute deviation

fields: A function, \(f\), is {{c1::translation invariant}} iff \[{{c2::f(x + c) = f(x)}}\]
For any constant \(c\).
A function, \(f\), has {{c1::positive homogeneity}} iff \[{{c2::f(kx) = k f(x)}}\]
For any constant \(k\).
A function, \(f\), is {{c1::subadditive}} iff \[{{c2::f(x + y) \leq f(x) + f(y)}}\]
For all \(x\) and \(y\). Note the similarity to the triangle inequality.

Given random loss variables \(X\) and \(Y\), then a risk measure \(\rho\) satisfies {{c1::first-order stochastic dominance monotinicity}} iff {{c2::\(\mathbb{P}\left(X \leq Y\right) = 1\) in the joint distribution implies that \(\rho(X) \leq \rho(Y)\)}}.
When the context is clear we will just say monotinicity.
